title: Eliphaz's Rebuke
shortSummary: In Job 15, Eliphaz the Temanite responds to Job with a stern rebuke, accusing him of speaking foolishly and questioning his righteousness before God. Eliphaz emphasizes human sinfulness, the consequences of wickedness, and the futility of trusting in vanity, reinforcing traditional wisdom about God's justice.
timeline: c. 2000 BC - Patriarchal Period, during the events of Job's trials

keyCharacters.name: Eliphaz the Temanite
keyCharacters.description: One of Job's three friends who speaks in this chapter, delivering a harsh critique of Job's words and character.

keyCharacters.name: Job
keyCharacters.description: The central figure of the book, whose suffering and questioning provoke Eliphaz's rebuke.

definitions.definition: A hot, dry, and often destructive wind from the east, symbolizing emptiness or futility in speech.
Sinful behavior or moral wrongdoing that separates man from God.
Those who pretend to be righteous but are inwardly corrupt and deceitful.
Futility or emptiness; something without lasting value or substance.

outline.heading: Eliphaz Challenges Job’s Wisdom and Speech
outline.description: Eliphaz begins by questioning the value of Job’s words, accusing him of speaking empty knowledge and choosing deceitful speech, asserting that Job’s own mouth condemns him.

outline.heading: The Question of Human Wisdom and Righteousness
outline.description: Eliphaz reminds Job of human limitations, emphasizing that no man is truly clean or righteous before God, and that even the heavens are not pure in His sight.

outline.heading: The Fate of the Wicked Described
outline.description: Eliphaz outlines the suffering and downfall that await the wicked, portraying their lives as full of pain, fear, and ultimate destruction, warning against trusting in vanity and deceit.

application: Guard your speech carefully, avoiding empty or deceitful words that can lead to condemnation.
Recognize human sinfulness and approach God with humility, understanding that no one is righteous by their own merit.
Trust in God's justice rather than in worldly prosperity or vain hopes.
Avoid hypocrisy by living a life consistent with genuine faith and obedience to God.

keyVerses.text: What is man, that he should be clean? and he which is born of a woman, that he should be righteous?
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the universal human condition of sinfulness and the impossibility of achieving righteousness apart from God.

keyVerses.text: Let not him that is deceived trust in vanity: for vanity shall be his recompence.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning against placing trust in empty or false hopes, emphasizing the consequences of deception.

keyVerses.text: Thine own mouth condemneth thee, and not I: yea, thine own lips testify against thee.
keyVerses.significance: Eliphaz asserts that Job’s own words reveal his guilt, underscoring the power of speech to expose the heart.
